Displaying error messages to the user is an essential part of form validation. Flask-WTF makes it easy to display error messages to the user. **Displaying error messages** To display error messages, you can use the `form.errors` attribute in your template. This attribute contains a dictionary of error messages for each field that didn't validate. Here's an updated version of your `contact.html` template: ```html Contact Me

Contact Me

{{ form.hidden_tag() }} {% if form.name.errors %}
    {% for error in form.name.errors %}
  • {{ error }}
    • {% endfor %}
{% endif %}

{% if form.email.errors %}
    {% for error in form.email.errors %}
  • {{ error }}
    • {% endfor %}
{% endif %}

{% if form.message.errors %}
    {% for error in form.message.errors %}
  • {{ error }}
    • {% endfor %}
{% endif %}

``` Here's what's changed: * We added `{{ form.hidden_tag() }}` to include any hidden fields generated by Flask-WTF. * We added error message displays for each field using `{% if form.field.errors %}` blocks. If there are errors for a field, we iterate over the `form.field.errors` list and display each error message as a list item. **How it works** When the form is submitted, Flask-WTF will validate the input data and populate the `form.errors` attribute with error messages for each field that didn't validate. In the template, we check if there are errors for each field using `form.field.errors`. If there are errors, we display them to the user. When the user submits the form, Flask-WTF will automatically redisplay the form with error messages if the form doesn't validate. This way, the user can see what went wrong and correct their input. That's it! You should now have a form with validation and error messages. If you have any more questions or need further help, feel free to ask.
